publicationStmt.p: Published by the Open Publishing Unit of The Pennsylvania State University Libraries.

monogr.author: Francis Beaumont
John Fletcher
monogr.title: Comedies and Tragedies Written by Francis Beavmont and Iohn Fletcher, Gentlemen. Never printed before, And now published by the Authours Originall Copies.

imprint.pubPlace: The Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard

front.head: This cast list has been adapted from the 1679 folio edition of Beaumont and Fletcher's Fifty Comedies and Tragedies. Spelling has been regularized based on how names appear in the dialogue, and new descriptions have been supplied.

castItem.roleDesc: ship's officer in charge of equipment and the crew
French Lord looking to buy land and lordship in a new country; banished from his country
a woman aboard the ship; under the protection of Albert
leader of the female commonwealth; a firm protector of the commonwealth
daughter of Rosella; raised by only women (aka, the commonwealth)

lg.l: Oh what a tempest have I in my stomach!
How my empty guts cry out! My wounds ache;
Would they but bleed again that I might get
Something to quench my thirst.
Oh, Lamure, the happiness my dogs had
When I kept house at home! They had a storehouse,
A storehouse of most blessed bones and crusts,
Happy crusts! Oh! How sharp hunger pinches me!
Oh, my importunate importunate: persistently troublesome, urgent belly, I have nothing
To satisfy thee. I have sought
As far as my weak legs would carry me
Yet can find nothing, neither meat nor water,
Nor anything that's nourishing.
My belly's grown together like an empty satchel.

div.stage: Enter Franville holding rocks, mud, and other debris.

lg.l: How now, what news?
Hast any meat yet?
Not a bit that I can see.
Here be goodly quarries quarries: reserves of stone, but they be cruel hard
To gnaw. I ha' got some mud—we'll eat it with spoons—
Very good thick mud, but it stinks damnably.
There's old rotten trunks of trees, too,
But not a leaf nor blossom in all the island.
How it looks—!
It stinks too.
It may be poison—
Let it be anything
So I can get it down. Why, man,

Poison's a princely dish. Poison's a princely dish: A possible version of the idiom: "one man's poison is another man's meat," essentially meaning "people have different tastes" or "value is relative." The idiom was used by Beaumont and Fletcher's contemporary Thomas Middleton in his 1604 work Plato's Cap ("That old moth-eaten proverb... One man's meat, is another man's poison"), though also by Beaumont himself in Love's Cure, which was also published for the first time in the 1647 folio: "What's one man's poison, Signor, is another's meat or drink." In a literal way, the palates of the shipwrecked nobles must shift from meat to mud ("poison"). At the same time, it may suggest that societal rules/morality are also relative: one man's good behavior (meat) is another one's bad (poison) and vice versa. But in the context of the shipwreck, "poison" suggests a kind of moral suspension: the behavior that was once deemed bad in society is no longer considered bad on the island.
Hast thou no biscuit?
No crumbs left in thy pocket? Here's my doublet doublet: close-fitting jacket worn primarily by men:
Give me but three small crumbs.
Not for three kingdoms,
If I were master of 'em. Oh, Lamure,
But one poor joint of mutton joint of mutton: portion of meat from an adult sheep, often considered less palatable than other meats —we have scorned scorned: acted contemptuously, man—
Thou speakest of paradise—
Or but the snuffs of those healths snuffs of those healths: dregs of drinks
We have lewdly lewdly: ignorantly, foolishly at midnight flung away!
Ah! But to lick the glasses!
Here comes the Surgeon. What
Hast thou discovered? Smile, smile and comfort us.
I am expiring;
Smile, they that can. I can find nothing, gentlemen;
Here's nothing can be meat without a miracle.
Oh, that I had my boxes boxes: surgical cupping glasses, or possibly lidded cases for ointments and lints lints: soft materials used for dressing wounds now,

My stupes stupes: medicinal pieces of cloths used on wounds, my tents tents: rolls of soft, absorbent material, which were often medicated and used to stop wounds from bleeding, and those sweet helps of nature;
What dainty dishes could I make of 'em.
Hast near Hast near: Do you have nearby an old suppository suppository: medicine administered through a bodily orifice, usually the rectum—?
Oh, would I had, sir.
Or but the paper where such a cordial cordial: comforting or reviving medicine or beverage,
Potion, or pills hath been entombed—

Or the blessed bladder bladder: prepared bladder of an animal, inflated and used as a receptacle for substances like medicine where a cooling clyster cooling clyster: plant-based medicine used for soothing fevers—
Hast thou no cereclothscerecloths: surgical plasters left?
Nor any old poulticepoultice: substance applied to the skin as part of a bandage?
We care not to what it hath been ministeredministered: applied—
Sure I have none of these daintiesdainties: delicacies, gentlemen.
Where's the great wen wen: wart, cyst, tumor, or other protuberance of the body
Thou cut'st from Hugh the sailor's shoulder?
That would serve now for a most princely banquet.
Ay, if we had it, gentlemen.
I flung it overboard, slave that I was—
A most unprovident villain!
If I had anything that were but supple now,
I could make salads of your shoes, gentlemen,
And rare ones; anything unctuous unctuous: meaty, greasy!
Ay, and then we might fry the soles i'th' sun;
The soles would make a second dish—
Or souse souse: brine, pickle 'em in the saltwater;
An inner sole well soused soused: pickled—
Here comes the woman.
It may be she has meat and may relieve us.
Let's withdraw, and mark mark: keep watch, and then be ready;
She'll hide her store store: collection of goods, in this case, food, else, and so cozen cozen: deceive or dupe us.
How weary and how hungry am I;
How feeble and how faint is all my body.
My sight forsaking me, and all my spirits,
As if they heard my passing bell passing bell: proverbially, death knell go for me,
Pull in their powers and give me up to destiny.
Oh! For a little water, a little, little meat,
A little to relieve me ere ere: before I perish.
I had whole floods of tears awhile that nourished me,
But they are all consumed for thee, dear Albert;
For thee they are spent spent: used up, worn out, for thou art dead;
Merciless fate hath swallowed thee.
Oh, I grow heavy; sleep is a salve salve: healing ointment for wounds or sores for misery.
Heaven, look on me and either take my life
Or make me once more happy.
She's fast asleep already!
Why should she have this blessing and we wake still,
Wake to our wants wants: shortages?
This thing hath been our overthrow,
And all these biting mischiefs that fall on us
Are come through her means.
True we were bound—ye all know—
For happy places and most fertile islands
Where we had constant promises of all things.
She turned the captain's mind
And must have him go in search, I know not of who,
Nor to what end—of such a fool, her brother,

And such a coxcomb coxcomb: a foolish person, or a vain man, her kinsman such a coxcomb, her kinsman: "coxcomb" primarily refers to a rooster's crest, or a "cock's comb." Given that jester hats resemble roosters' crests, and jesters are fools, the word "coxcomb" evolved to describe not only the jester's cap but fools themselves. The word "coxcomb" can also describe a vain, pretentious, and foppish person, perhaps because roosters are viewed as prideful. In other words, someone described as a coxcomb pretends to be stylish and educated. As jesters are the noble's personal comedians and storytellers, Franville's use takes on additional meaning. The insult could imply that Aminta's relative is pseudo-nobility who amuses other nobles with attempts at legitimacy. Given that the men believe it is okay for superiors eat their inferiors, Franville's disqualification of Aminta's family may also justify his turn to cannibalism (OED).—
And we must put in put in: make harbor everywhere;
She has put us in now, i'faith.
Why should we consume consume: waste away thus and starve—
Have nothing to relieve us—
And she live there that bred all our miseries,
Unroasted or unsod unsod: unboiled, uncooked?
I have read in stories—
Of such restoring meats
We have examples,

Thousand examples and allowed for excellent Thousand examples ... excellent: Discourse on cannibalism in the early modern period became more prevalent following European contact with real and imagined cannibals in North and South America. Cannibalism in the Americas was largely reviled by Europeans. However, during the period this play was written there was also a medicinal cannibalistic practices thriving throughout Europe. The medicinal discourse between Lamure, Morillat, Franville, and the Surgeon earlier in the play are relevant to this discussion in that they consider eating a "wen" that was pulled from one of the sailor's shoulders during the voyage. Prior to this, the group primarily discusses tools of medicine; the brief mention of "cordials," "potions," and "pills" takes on a different meaning due to many medications being made from human parts, with some of the most common sources being blood and bone (Sugg).:
Women that have eat their children,
Men their slaves—nay their brothers—but these are nothing!
Husbands devoured their wives (they are their chattels chattels: possessions, goods, often with relation to livestock),
And of a schoolmaster that, in time of famine,
Powdered up Powdered up: Seasoned with salt or pickled all his scholars.
She's young and tidy tidy: healthy.
In my conscience, she'll eat delicately
Just like young pork; a little lean.
Your opinion, Surgeon?
I think she may be made good meat.
But look, we shall want want: lack salt.
Tush Tush: contemptuous, impatient exclamation, she needs no powdering powdering: salt seasoning .
I grant ye;

But to suck out the humorous parts suck out the humorous parts: In pre-modern physiology, the humors were four different fluids in the body; when imbalanced, one's body and mood risked falling out of health and displaying the symptoms related to the type of imbalance. The word "humorous" is also used to mean moody or capricious. Being a doctor (and thus knowledgeable of the humors), the Surgeon wishes to remove them from Aminta's body before the men eat her. Yet the act of removing her humors is telling. In one way, he expresses concern for his health by emptying the humors: if he were to eat Aminta's humors, he could contract an imbalance—whether an excess or a deficit—of his own humors. At the same time, Aminta is female and so stereotyped in early modern drama as capricious and changeable. This could suggest the Surgeon fears he could contract her emotionality over his "balanced" male rationality if he were to eat her. This line could also be read, more simply, as an indication of the Surgeon's desire to eat the humorous (i.e. "juicy") parts of her body.— by all means
Let's kill her in a chase, she'll eat the sweeter.
Let's kill her any way, and kill her quickly
That we might be at our meat.
How if the captain—
Talk not of him! He's dead, and the rest famished.
Wake her, Surgeon, and cut her throat;
And then divide her, every man his share—
She wakes herself.
Holy and good things keep me!
What cruel dreams have I had. Who are these?
Oh, they are my friends. For heaven's sake, gentlemen,
A little to relieve me. I may bless ye,
For weak and wretched, ready to perish,
Even now I die.
You'll save a labor, then.
You bred these miseries and you shall pay for't.
We have no meat, nor where to have we know not,
Nor how to pull ourselves from these afflictions.
We are starved, too, famished; all our hopes deluded deluded: deceived.
Yet ere ere: before we die thus, we'll have one dainty meal.
Shall I be with ye, gentlemen?
Yes, marry marry: expression of surprise used to emphasize what follows, shall ye; in our bellies, lady.
We love you well—
What said you, sir?
Marry Marry: expression of surprise used to emphasize what follows, we'll eat your ladyship—
You that have buried us in this base base: of low quality or worth island;
We'll bury ye in a more noble noble: fine, splendid monuments.
Will ye say your prayers that I may perform, lady?
We are wonderous sharp-set sharp-set: acutely hungry. Come, gentlemen,
Who are for the hinder hinder: rear parts?
I—
And I!
Be patient;
They will not fall to every man's share.
Oh hear me,
Hear me, ye barbarous men!
Be short and pithy pithy: full of concentrated meaning,
Our stomachs cannot stay stay: abide a long discourse—
And be not fearful,
For I'll kill ye daintily—
Are ye not Christians?
Why, do not Christians eat women?
Eat one another? 'Tis most impious impious: not pitiful, devoted, or faithful.
Come, come—
Oh! Help! Help! Help!
The lady's voice! Stand off, slaves!
What do you intend, villains?
I have strength enough left me, if you abuse this soul,
To—
They would have ravished her, upon my life!
Speak, how was it, lady?
Forgive 'em, 'twas their hungers—
Ha, their hungers!
They would have eaten her.
Oh, damned villains! Speak, is it true?
I confess an appetite.
An appetite? I'll fit ye for an appetite!

Are ye so sharp-set sharp-set: The use of "sharp-set" in this passage is layered. As an adjective, it describes a strong hunger (OED). However, it is also a word used to describe hawks, hounds, and other hunting animals and their eagerness for predatory behavior. That said, this use of "sharp-set" figures the shipwrecked nobles as savage beasts. Yet another definition of "sharp-set" is "having a craving for sexual indulgence," which also promotes the connection between food and sexual craving that appears throughout the passage. For example, with the first use of sharp-set, the men argue over who gets to eat her buttocks, and with the second use, Tibalt asks if the men are so hungry that Aminta's "flesh" must "serve" them, here again evoking sexual indulgence. As Aminta is the only woman on the barren island, it is worth noting that the cannibalism directed towards her—i.e. to consume her—is meant to be read as a sexual metaphor. that her flesh must serve you?
Murder's a main main: powerful good service with your worships.
Since ye would be such devils,
Why did you not begin with one another handsomely handsomely: fittingly; also, liberally
And spare the woman to beget more food on beget more food on: i.e. Aminta may produce children which will serve as further food?
Good sir—
You shall grow mummy mummy: beaten to a pulpy substance, rascals!
I'll make you fall to your brawns brawns: fleshy or muscular parts of the body and your buttocks
And worry worry: choke with a mouthful of food one another like keen bandogs bandogs: ferocious dogs chained or tied up to guard a house!
Good sir, be merciful.
You shall know what 'tis to be damned cannibals!
Oh, my best friend!
Alas, poor heart! Here,
Here's some meat and sovereign drink sovereign drink: efficacious or potent remedy to ease you.
Sit down, gentle sweet.
I am blessed to see you.
Stir not within forty foot of this food!
If you do, dogs—
Oh, captain! Captain! Captain!
Ye shall have meat, all of you—
Captain, hear me first. Hark!
'Tis so inhumane I would not ha' the air corrupted with it—
Oh, barbarous men! Sit down, du-Pont,
Good Master, and honest sailors.
But stand you off
And wait upon wait upon: serve our charity—I'll wait on wait on: serve; presumably a threat of violence you, else—
And touch nothing but what's flung at thee, as if you were dogs;
If you do, I'll cut your fingers. Friends,
I'll spoil your carving.

div.stage: Aminta gives food to gentlemen and Sailors.

lg.l: There, wretches, there.
Eat your meat handsomely handsomely: fittingly; also, liberally now,
And give heaven thanks.
There's more bread.
See, they snarl like dogs.
Eat quietly, you rascals, eat quietly.
There is drink, too.
Come, come, I'll fill you each your cups,
Ye shall not surfeit surfeit: suffer from over indulgence in food or drink.
And what have you discovered?
Sweet, a paradise,
A paradise inhabited with angels
Such as you are; their pities make 'em angels.
They gave me these viands viands: provisions and supplied me
With these precious drinks.
Shall we not see 'em?
Yes, they will see you
Out of their charities. Having heard our story
They will come and comfort us. Come presently.
We shall no more know wants wants: shortages nor miseries.
Are they all women?
All, and all in love with us—
How!
Do not mistake: in love with our misfortunes;
They will cherish and relieve our men.
Do you shrug now
And pull up your noses? You smell comfort.
See, they stretch out their legs like dottrels dottrels: fools,

Each like a new Saint Denis Saint Denis: martyred third-century French saint who is said to have carried his head for several miles after he was beheaded. Tibalt implies the sailors only attend to their bodily needs and desires (Bourne).
Dear mistress,
When you would name me and the women hear,
Call me your brother, you I'll call my sister,
And pray observe this all—
Why do you change color, sweet?
Eating too much meat.
Sauced with jealousy.
Fie, fie Fie, fie: exclamation inciting shame, usually said to children, dear saint, i'faith ye are too blame.
Are ye not here? Here, fixed in my heart?

div.stage: Enter Rosella, Clarinda, Crocale, Hippolita, and Juletta.

lg.l: Hark, hark!
They are come. Stand ready, and look nobly nobly: splendidly, magnificently,
And with all humble reverence receive 'em.
Our lives depend upon their gentle pities
And death waits on their anger.
Sure they are fairies.
Be they devils, devils of flesh and blood,
After so long a Lent Lent: referring to the Christian time of abstinence and repentance and tedious voyage
To me they are angels.
Oh for some eryngoes eryngoes: aphroditic plants!
Potatoes or cantharides cantharides: dried beetles used as aphrodisiac—
Peace, you rogues that buy abilities buy abilities: buy medicines thought to enhance sexual performance of your 'pothecaries.
Had I but took the diet of green cheese
And onions for a month, I could do wonders. Had I ... wonders: presumably this diet was thought to improve one's sexual performance
Are these the jewels you run mad for?
What can you see in one of these
To whom you would vouchsafe vouchsafe: acknowledge or bestow in some favorable manner a gentle touch?
Can nothing persuade you
To love yourselves and place your happiness
In cold and chaste embraces of each other?
This is from the purpose.
We had your grant grant: consent to have them as they were.
'Tis a beauteous creature,
And to myself I do appear deformed
When I consider her. And yet she is
The stranger's sister. Why then should I fear?
She cannot prove my rival.
When you repent
That you refused my counsel, may it add
To your afflictions that you were forewarned
Yet leapt into the gulf of your misfortunes.
But have your wishes.
Now she makes to us.
I am instructed. But take heed, Albert,
You prove not false false: deceitful—
Ye are your own assurance,
And so acquainted with your own perfections
That weak doubts cannot reach you. Therefore, fear not.
That you are poor and miserable men
My eyes inform me; that without our succors succors: aids, assistances
Hope cannot flatter you to dream of safety.
The present plight you are in can resolve resolve: alter so as to form a concord you
That to be merciful is to draw near
The heavenly essence. Whether you will be
Thankful, I do not question, nor demand
What country bred you—what names, what manners—
To us it is sufficient we relieve
Such as have shapes of men. And I command you,
As we are not ambitious to know
Farther of you, that on pain of death
You presume not to enquire what we are
Or whence whence: from where derived.
In all things we obey you,
And thankfully we ever shall confess

Ourselves your creatures Ourselves your creatures: In this passage, Albert pledges the men's subservience to Rosella and appears to reverse the patriarchal assumptions of early modern social relations. "Creatures," in this sense, likely refers to someone "who owes his fortune or position, and remains subservient to, a patron," and who also is "ready to do another's bidding" (OED). According to Albert, then, the Frenchmen are not only willing to subjugate themselves to these women, but also are willing to do their bidding (sexually or otherwise). What makes this passage especially interesting is how quickly its effects are reversed; just ten lines later, Rosella cedes power back to the men. These quick-shifting dynamics are likely related to the comedic genre of the play, as the playwrights keep switching back and forth between giving their French protagonists patriarchal power and taking it away from them..
You speak as becomes you.
First, then, and willingly, deliver up
Those weapons we could force from you.
Most gladly at your feet.
I have had many a combat with a tall wench,
But never was disarmed before.
And now hear comfort:
Your wants wants: shortages shall be supplied, and though it be
A debt women may challenge to be sued to—
Especially from such they may command—
We give up to you that power, and therefore,
Freely each make his choice.
Then here I fix—
Nay, she is mine; I eyed her first—
This mine—
StayStay: Stop, halt, good rascals.
You are too forward forward: eager; also, immodest, sir gallant gallant: man of fashion;
You are not giving order to a tailor
For the fashion of a new suit.
Nor are you in your warehouse, master merchant.
Stand back and give your betters leave—your betters—
And grumble not; if ye do, as I love meat
I will so swinge swinge: beat, flog, or whip the salt itch salt itch: sexual desire out on on: of you.
Captain, Master, and the rest of us
That are brothers and good fellows, we have been
Too late by the ears by the ears: gathered to fight and yet smart smart: feel pain for our follies.
To end therefore all future emulation emulation: ambitious rivalry for power or honor, if you please,
Trust to my election; you shall say
I am not partial to myself, I doubt not,
Give contentcontent: satisfaction to all.
Agreed, agreed.
Then but observe how learnèd and discreetly
I will proceed and, as a skillful doctor
In all the quirks belongs to the game,
Read over your complexions. For you, captain,
Being first in place and therefore first to be served,
I give my judgment thus: for your aspect aspect: outward appearance, particularly the face
Y'are much inclined to melancholy, and that tells me
The sullen Saturn had predominance
At your nativity—a malignant malignant: damaging or harmful planet,
And if not qualified by a sweet conjunction
Of a soft and ruddy wench born under Venus Venus: Roman goddess of beauty and love, here referring also to the planet,
It may prove fatal—therefore, to your arms

I give this rose-cheeked virgin. For you ... rose-cheeked virgin: As Tibalt explains how he selected a partner for Albert, he refers to astrology, saying that Albert was born under Saturn, "a malignant planet," which caused him to be prone to melancholy. In the early modern period, the medical belief in the humoral system still persisted. This meant that there were four bodily "humors": phlegm, yellow bile, blood, and black bile, that could cause various issues if these fluids were unbalanced. Melancholy was the term for an excess of black bile. The humoral system often was used in conjunction with theories about the planets (namely, the moon, Mars, Venus, Jupiter, and Saturn). In this case, Tibalt selects Clarinda because he claims that she is a "soft, ruddy wench born under Venus." This, according to Tibalt should restore Albert's balance and counteract his melancholic tendencies. Melancholy was also blamed for hallucinations, sudden outbursts, and other signs of madness.
To my wish!
'Til now I never was happy.
Nor I accursed!
Master, you are old
Yet love the game—that I perceive, too—
And if not well spurred up spurred up: ready to ride, used as sexual innuendo you may prove rusty.
Therefore, to help ye here's a Bradamanta Bradamanta: fictional female warrior and expert in combat
Or I am cozenedcozened: deceived or duped in my calculation.
A poor old man allotted to my share—
Thou wouldst have two—
Nay, I think twenty—but fear not, wench:
Though he be old he's tough. Look on's making,
He'll not fail, I warrant thee—
A merry fellow,
And were not man a creature I detest
I could endure his company—
Here's a fair herd of does before me.
And now for a barren one,
For though I like the sport, I do not love
To father children. Like the Grand Signor Grand Signor: Ottoman Sultan,
Thus I walk in my seraglio seraglio: the part of a Muslim palace where wives and concubines live
And view 'em as I pass, then draw I forth
My handkerchief and, having made my choice,
I thus bestow it—
On me?
On you. Now my choice is made,
To it, you hungry rascals.
Excellent.
As I love goodness,
It makes me smile i'th' height of all my fears.
What a strong contention you may behold
Between my mother's mirth and anger.
Nay, no coyness. Be mistress of your word:
I must and will enjoy you.
Be advised, fool: alas, I am old.
How canst thou hope content content: satisfaction from one that's fifty?
Never talk on't.
I have known good ones at threescore threescore: sixty and upwards.
Besides, the weather's hot, and men
That have experience fear fevers;
A temperate diet is the only physicphysic: curative.

Your juleps juleps: sweet drinks made with syrup or sugar nor guajacum guajacum: drug prepared from the resin of a tree of the West Indies, prunellos prunellos: plums; also, liqueurs derived from the fruit of the blackthorn,
Camphor Camphor: a bitter pharmaceutical substance used as an antaphrodisiac pills, nor gourd water gourd water: rain water collected in a hollowed-out gourd (Bourne).,
Come not near your old woman.
Youthful stomachs are still craving
Though there be nothing left to stop their mouths with.
And believe me, I am no frequent giver of those bounties I am no frequent ... bounties: i.e. I do not often engage in sexual activity—
Laugh on, laugh on, good gentlemen, do.
I shall make holiday and sleep when you
Dig in the mines 'til your hearts ache.
A mad fellow.
Well, sir, I'll give you hearing, and as I like
Your wooing and discourse—but I must tell ye, sir,
That rich widows look for great sums in present rich widows ... present: i.e. rich widows expect large sums of money as gifts
Or assurances of ample jointers jointers: joint possessors of property or an estate.
That to me is easy,
For instantly I'll do it: hear, comrades!
What say'st thou, Tibalt?
Why, that to woo a wench with empty hands
Is no good heraldry heraldry: show of honor and noble birth. Therefore, let's to the gold
And share it equally; 'twill speak for us
More than a thousand compliments or cringes cringes: bows, deferential acts,
Ditties stolen from Patrick Patrick: likely misspelling of Petrarch, Italian Renassiance author of famous love sonnets, or discourse from Ovid Ovid: ancient Roman poet of great renown.
Besides, 'twill beget us respect,
And if ever Fortune friend us with a bark bark: wooden ship,
Largely supply us with all provision.
Well advised; defer it not.
Are ye all contented?
We are!
Let's away then.
Straight we'll return
And you shall see our riches.
Since I know Since I know: Since I have known what wonder and amazement was,
I ne'er was so transported transported: carried away by excitement.
Why weep ye, gentle maid?
There is no danger here to such as you.
Banish fear, for with us I dare promise
You shall meet all courteous entertainment.
We esteem esteem: regard as valuable ourselves most happy in you—
And bless fortune that brought you hither.
Hark in your ear:
I love you as a friend already.
Ere Ere: Before long you shall call me by a nearer name. Ere long ... nearer name: i.e. Soon you will call me your sister-in-law
I wish your brother well; I know you apprehend me.
(Ay, to my grief, I do.)
Alas, good ladies, there is nothing left me
But thanks to pay ye with.
That's more
Than yet you stand engaged for.

div.stage: Enter Albert, Tibalt, and the rest with treasure.

lg.l: So soon returned!

Here: see the idol of the lapidary. lapidary: an individual who is skilled in the work surrounding gems and precious stones
idol of lapidary: The phrase "idol of lapidary" begins a series of descriptions of the treasure by the Frenchmen that seemingly elevates its value to a mythical quality through associations with a diverse variety of individuals—slaves, merchants, royalty, sailors—who would go to immense lengths to possess it. "Idol of lapidary" also implies that the treasure is a divine object of worship, perhaps even beyond one's love of God. While these descriptions aim to impress Rosella, in a larger sense they function to afford the men themselves material value alongside their sexual value to the women. It is therefore of utmost importance to the Frenchmen to upsell the value of the treasure. Furthermore, in a narrative with characters like Lamure, Franville, and Morillat, whose identities are strongly rooted in their material wealth (as first seen in Act 1, Scene 1 during the storm), perhaps these people-related descriptions of value mirror their own views on persona and reflect a genuine desire for such treasure to re-establish their identities.
These pearls for which the slavish negro
Dives to the bottom of the sea—
To get which the industrious merchant
Touches at either pole Touches at either pole: Traverses the globe—
The never-sailing purchase
Of lordships and of honors—
The world's mistress
That can give everything to the possessors—
For which the sailors scorn scorn: defy tempestuous winds
And spit defiance in the sea—
Speak, lady: look we not lovely now?

Yes, yes—oh, my stars oh, my stars: Rosella's call of gratitude to the stars for bringing her an opportunity for revenge subtly contrasts Albert's earlier pleas to a Christian heaven. While both reference some type of higher force intertwined with the Christian beliefs of the time, Rosella references a naturalistic force that, in a larger sense, emphasizes the women's eschewing of societal and religious conventions in their isolated environment. The women are previously characterized alongside the Greek goddess Artemis as independent, chaste hunters and with Artemis' associations with the moon. Here, the women appeal to a Greek, polytheistic religion that places belief in the power of celestial bodies like the moon and the stars. This association also perhaps alludes to the idea of women constantly changing and being influenced by nature. Taken together with the men's references to conventional Christian ideas of God and heaven, a rhetorical battle is created not only between spiritual worldviews, but also between genders.,
Be now forever blessed that have brought
To my revenge these robbers! Take your arrows
And nail these monsters to the earth.
What mean ye, lady?
In what have we offended?
Oh, my daughter
And you companions with me in all fortunes!
Look on these caskets and these jewels.
These were our own when first we put to sea
With good Sebastian, and these the pirates
That, not alone deprived him of his treasure,
But also took his life.

l.seg: Part of my present Part of my present: i.e. Part of what was presented to me by the French men

lg.l: I well remember was mine own.
And these were mine.
Sure, I have worn this jewel.
Wherefore do ye staystay: delay, then,
And not perform my command?
Oh, heaven!
What cruel fate pursues us?
I am well enough served

That must be offering jointures jointures: The original definition of "jointure" is rooted in marriage conventions, referring to an arrangement between a husband and wife to hold a property jointly so that the property may be settled on the wife if she is widowed. It also has been used an equivalent term to a dowry. Tibalt's use of "jointures," then, might allude to the societal and patriarchal need to establish order through marital and legal conventions, particularly as this usage occurs in the face of a woman's (Rosella's) anger. However, the suggested convention of "jointure" is one of the few of its time that gave women potential independence over their estate, and so it may also be rhetorically appropriate that Tibalt offers a share of further wealth to Rosella who is presumed to be widowed (Habakkuk, 15). It is also possible that jointure's associations with dowry suggest that an intense situation of environment isolated from societal norms could lead to a switch in gender roles, such as a man freely offering dowry directly to a woman. jewels,
And precious stones more than I brought with me.
Why shoot ye not?
Hear me, dear mother,
And when the greatest cruelty is justice,
Do not show mercy: death to these starved wretches
Is a reward, not punishment. Let 'em live
To undergo the full weight of your displeasure,
And that they may have sense to feel the torments
They have deserved, allow 'em some small pittance pittance: very small offering of something, in this case, nourishment
To linger out their tortures.
'Tis well counselled,
And we'll follow it.
Hear us speak—
Peace, dogs!
Bind 'em fast. When fury hath given way to reason The women tie up the men with ropes.
I will determine of their sufferings
Which shall be horrid. Vengeance, though slow-paced,
At length o'ertakes the guilty, and the wrath
Of the incensed powers will fall most sure
On wicked men when they are most secure.

interpGrp.interp: Words or phrases related to food/drink or eating/drinking.
Words or phrases that refer to objects present on stage.
Words or phrases related to places, including specific geographic locations, that characters are, have been, or imagine going.
Words or phrases related to religion or spiritual practices.
Words or phrases that are names or represent people.
